text1: The state should abide by the precautionary principle. Genetically modified crops should not be used unless it is certain that no harmful consequences will be caused by their use.
text2: Genetically modified crops can only be grown if they are approved for use by the appropriate regional agency, who will only do so if there is scientific evidence that they will not harm the environment or people.

text1: While many agricultural practices may be seen as similar to modern-day genetic modification, the former have often been used throughout history, while the latter is a recent phenomenon. With this in mind, the similarities are not enough to conclude that modern GMO foods pose no greater risks than long-established, non-GMO ones.
text2: Many of the processes employed in genetic modification have occurred, in nature and in traditional agriculture, for years without any identifiable health risks. As such, it seems unlikely that GMOs pose a greater risk than non-GMOs.

text1: Genetically modified crops can be harmful to the environment and ecosystems, threatening biodiversity.
text2: Intensive agriculture as a whole, not specifically GMO farming, threatens biodiversity.

text1: Genetically modified crops can be harmful to the environment and ecosystems, threatening biodiversity.
text2: Genetic modification can be used to prevent certain crops from becoming extinct, fighting against biodiversity loss.

text1: Genetically modified crops can be harmful to the environment and ecosystems, threatening biodiversity.
text2: GM crops are often modified in ways that can make them better for the environment than their unmodified counterparts.

text1: Out-crossing or hybridisation can easily occur, whereby a GM crop cross-pollinates with a reproductively compatible non-GMO species. This may lead to reduced biodiversity.
text2: Out-crossing is already a naturally-occurring and vitally beneficial phenomenon in a diverse range of land plants with self-incompatibility, encouraging the essential generation of new genotypes in plants for continued successful survival.

text1: Out-crossing or hybridisation can easily occur, whereby a GM crop cross-pollinates with a reproductively compatible non-GMO species. This may lead to reduced biodiversity.
text2: Those conducting genetic modification can carefully monitor and control GM species to prevent this happening.

text1: If genetically modified animals are released into the wild or accidentally escape, they could threaten the continued survival of their wild, non-GM counterparts.
text2: GMOs simply accelerate or generate processes of natural selection and the survival of the fittest, thus there are unlikely to be any unnatural, long-term effects on biodiversity.

text1: The accelerated growth rates of some genetically modified fish may mean they could outcompete the wild population for food if released.
text2: The general scientific consensus is that it is not yet clear whether accelerated growth rates of GM fish would increase or reduce their ability to compete with native fish in the wild.

text1: Though GM crops typically reduce the need for multiple different herbicides, they have greatly increased the use of glyphosate, which can have immediately harmful environmental effects.
text2: Genetically modified crops reduce the use of pesticides, herbicides, fertilisers, and other chemical additives.

text1: Increased use of glyphosate-containing herbicides in conjunction with herbicide-resistant GMO crops causes the development of glyphosate-resistant "superweeds", leading to a renewed increase in economically and environmentally costly herbicides and farming practices.
text2: Genetically modified crops reduce the use of pesticides, herbicides, fertilisers, and other chemical additives.

text1: If genetically modified animals are released into the wild or accidentally escape, they could threaten the continued survival of their wild, non-GM counterparts.
text2: This can be of benefit, as in the case of mosquitoes that are genetically modifed to pass on a self-limiting gene to the wild population, thus reducing the transmission of mosquito-borne diseases.

text1: Reports about the proliferation of these genes in the wild population have so far proven inconclusive.
text2: This can be of benefit, as in the case of mosquitoes that are genetically modifed to pass on a self-limiting gene to the wild population, thus reducing the transmission of mosquito-borne diseases.

text1: If a species is going extinct naturally, humans should not intervene: such extinction is a natural part of evolution.
text2: Genetic modification can be used to prevent certain crops from becoming extinct, fighting against biodiversity loss.

text1: Some insects in the southern US are also developing resistance to "final Bt stronghold" altered strains, nearly definitively proving the superiority of insects over these Bt-altered genetic crops.
text2: The bacterial Bt gene produces a protein toxic to insects. Scientists have successfully transferred this gene into certain genetically modified crops, enabling them to produce insecticidal proteins.

text1: Insects are evolving to develop resistance to GM crops engineered to deter them.
text2: Insect resistance genes can be inserted into crops from other species, negating the need for insecticide whilst also protecting crops.

text1: Insects are evolving to develop resistance to GM crops engineered to deter them.
text2: The benefits can be sustained so long as farmers maintain refuge areas, where non-GM crops are planted in order to maintain a non-resistant gene in the local insect population (p. 13).

text1: Insects are evolving to develop resistance to GM crops engineered to deter them.
text2: Biotech companies are combating the resistance to GM crops by developing a variety of Bt strains targeting Bt-resistant insects.

text1: It is important to keep a balance between insect-resistant GM crops and non-GM crops in order to avoid "selection pressure," causing surviving insects with natural immunity to modified genes to mate with each other and increase the likelihood that future generations will also inherit the same immunity.
text2: Insect resistance genes can be inserted into crops from other species, negating the need for insecticide whilst also protecting crops.

text1: Increased use of glyphosate-containing herbicides in conjunction with herbicide-resistant GMO crops causes the development of glyphosate-resistant "superweeds", leading to a renewed increase in economically and environmentally costly herbicides and farming practices.
text2: In 2010, weed scientists estimated that the total amount of US farmland afflicted by such resistant weeds was still relatively small (p. 73).

text1: Traditional cross-breeding is proving to be more successful at adapting crops to drought and poor soils than GM techniques.
text2: Climate change will worsen soil conditions (p. 2-3). GM crops crops can mitigate or adapt to this phenomenon.

text1: Farmers can use anaerobic digesters to harvest the methane produced by their livestock so that it can be used as a farm energy source.
text2: On average per year, cows produce 70kg to 120kg of methane, which is a powerful greenhouse gas. Genetically modifying cows to emit less methane could thus greatly reduce global greenhouse gas emissions.

text1: The potential risks associated with excess exposure are outweighed by the established positive impact on oral health.
text2: Exposure to fluoride from multiple sources can lead to excessive exposure and potential health risks.

text1: Water fluoridation is a means of promoting public health equity.
text2: Sociological research on fluoridation has been built on a number of assumptions.

text1: According to the Center for Disease Control, fluoridated water in community drinking water has played a major role in the declining rates of tooth decay.
text2: Advances in dentistry such as tooth paste, tooth brushes, dental drills could have skewed the results.

text1: Wild animals do not drink from public water systems regularly, therefore would not be impacted by any form of community water fluoridation.
text2: Water fluoridation is harmful to wild animals.

text1: Research reported by the Center for Disease Control showed levels of fluoride present in water are safe for the environment, including plants and animals. (p. 6)
text2: Water fluoridation is harmful to wild animals.

text1: Fluoride in water is a fluoride ion (from rock) that incorporates readily into tooth enamel.  It is not a gas.  Therefore, this fear is unjustified.
text2: If water fluoridation leads to CFCs by means of the hydrogen cycle it would contribute to the loss of O3 in the upper atmosphere.

text1: A research evaluation found that water fluoridation in municipal settings did not negatively impact the environment.
text2: Fluoridating water is bad for the environment.

text1: People are not forced to drink community water. Other alternatives, such as bottled or filtered water, are available.
text2: People should have the right to choose what substance they ingest. When drinking fluoridated water this right is removed.

text1: The European Union’s Scientific Committee on Environmental Risks concluded that “the fluoride ion will not readily pass through the skin and this pathway is not likely to contribute to people’s fluoride intake.”
text2: Fluoride can be absorbed through skin. There are no practical alternative to this, as water is needed in other ways than ingestion.

text1: Water fluoridation is consistent with other accepted public health interventions that aim to enhance the well-being of communities.
text2: Water fluoridation raises ethical questions about mass medication.

text1: Water fluoridation is consistent with other accepted public health interventions that aim to enhance the well-being of communities.
text2: Water fluoridation lacks individual control and consent, distinguishing it from other public health interventions that respect personal autonomy.

text1: Water that has been fluoridated is similar to fortifying salt with iodine, milk with vitamin D, orange juice with calcium and bread with folic acid.
text2: The fortification of foods with iodine, vitamin D, and calcium is different in that it is avoidable.

text1: Water fluoridation saves money spent on dental treatments.
text2: The practice of water fluoridation is not feasible or cost effective in many regions.

text1: For most cities, every $1 invested in water fluoridation saves $38 in dental treatment costs.
text2: The cost-effectiveness of water fluoridation should be considered in the context of broader healthcare priorities. Other interventions could provide a more comprehensive and cost-effective approach to improving overall health, not just dental health.

text1: Since water is a public good, fluoridated water is an ideal method for distributing the health benefits of fluoridation.
text2: Based on this argument we should also consider adding essential vitamins, minerals, and nutrients to the water.

text1: Tap water already contains minerals and nutrients, with some jurisdictions mandating minimum levels for health reasons.
text2: Based on this argument we should also consider adding essential vitamins, minerals, and nutrients to the water.

text1: Fluoride is naturally present in all water sources.
text2: Water fluoridation violates the right to consent to medication.

text1: Fluoride is naturally present in all water sources.
text2: If there's already fluoride in water, adding more can lead to excess amounts of fluoride ions in drinking water which can cause arthritis, bone damage and osteoporosis.

text1: As dental caries is a public health concern, applying public health ethics is more appropriate than generic clinical ethics.
text2: Water fluoridation violates the right to consent to medication.

text1: Since dental caries affect a substantial portion of the population, the ethical duty to promote the well-being of the community justifies the implementation of water fluoridation.
text2: The most effective way to prevent tooth decay is by regularly brushing your teeth well and strengthening them with fluoride.

text1: Water sources naturally contain fluoride.
text2: Fluoridating water is bad for the environment.

text1: Water sources naturally contain fluoride.
text2: The industrial fluorides added to the water supply are (Fluosilicic acid, and Sodium Fluoride) which are not found in natural water sources. These man made fluorides are unstable and bind to the calcium in your body.

text1: Water sources naturally contain fluoride.
text2: 'Naturally occurring' does not inherently mean a substance is acceptable for human consumption.

text1: The amount of fluoride contained in bottled water is not required to be listed on the product label unless the label makes a claim about the product’s fluoride content.
text2: Iodine, vitamin D, etc. are listed in the ingredients whereas fluoride is not indicated at the source of consumption.

text1: While tap water is provided, nobody is obligated to drink it. Should someone desire, they could purchase non-fluoridated water for consumption.
text2: The fortification of foods with iodine, vitamin D, and calcium is different in that it is avoidable.

text1: Vegetarian diets tend to be high in dietary fiber which supports a healthy gut microbiome and digestive health.
text2: Excessive fiber intake can lead to digestive issues for some individuals, such as gas, constipation, IBS or abdominal pain.

text1: While these diets are higher in fiber, they are not excessively high. Nevertheless, high fiber can cause these problems for some individuals but these are relatively few and their bodies usually adapt to it over time.
text2: Excessive fiber intake can lead to digestive issues for some individuals, such as gas, constipation, IBS or abdominal pain.

text1: Vegetarian diets are based on nutrient-rich plant foods with many benefits.
text2: Many chemicals are used in plant-food production which can harm the overall health.

text1: Vegetarian diets are based on nutrient-rich plant foods with many benefits.
text2: Vegetarian diets are not always adequate for more vulnerable populations like children and pregnant women.

text1: Humans are anatomically herbivorous.
text2: Humans are omnivores: we are designed to eat a variety of food types and sources in order to thrive.

text1: Humans are anatomically herbivorous.
text2: Human dentition indicates that the human diet is by nature omnivorous.

text1: Studies indicate or show many prehistoric humans ate many plants and could well have been vegetarians.
text2: Prehistoric humans also ate insects and meat. Their diet was closer to the so-called "paleo diet."

text1: The human body naturally produces creatine on its own, and it is not necessary to get it through diet.
text2: While the body does produce creatine on its own, the levels of creatine may be lower than what is required, creating the need for supplements.

text1: Meat does not help build muscle mass, instead, specific exercise regimes build muscle mass in conjunction with a suitable protein and energy intake.
text2: Meat helps increasing and maintaining muscle mass.

text1: Meat does not help build muscle mass, instead, specific exercise regimes build muscle mass in conjunction with a suitable protein and energy intake.
text2: Meat does help build muscle mass since it is high in saturated fats which are optimum for muscle growth.

text1: Most body builders supplement their protein intake with protein shakes made from powder.
text2: Protein shakes are unnecessary for bodybuilders aiming to build muscle and burn fat. Complete amino acids essential for post-workout recovery are readily available in whole foods.

text1: The optimal amount of protein for muscle-building is 1.6 grams per kg bodyweight and in rare cases (e.g. older age and professional) slightly higher. Such amounts are usually not consumable daily with conventional healthy vegetarian diets that don't include protein powders at least during caloric restriction times when they reduce the percentage of bodyfat.
text2: Protein shakes are unnecessary for bodybuilders aiming to build muscle and burn fat. Complete amino acids essential for post-workout recovery are readily available in whole foods.

text1: Many plant toxins, also known as phytochemicals, are beneficial to humans through a phenomenon known as hormesis.
text2: Plants can be toxic and can't be tolerated by some people.

text1: The modern "paleo" diets are now thought to be based on a myth and in addition are not healthy.
text2: Prehistoric humans also ate insects and meat. Their diet was closer to the so-called "paleo diet."

text1: A shift toward vegetarianism can contribute to sustainable food production and avoid the use of unhealthy chemicals.
text2: Many chemicals are used in plant-food production which can harm the overall health.

text1: Nothing proves these are sufficiently present in the washed and/or cooked food to represent a notable health risk.
text2: Many chemicals are used in plant-food production which can harm the overall health.

text1: Vegetarian diets are based on nutrient-rich plant foods with many benefits.
text2: Humans are omnivores: we are designed to eat a variety of food types and sources in order to thrive.

text1: Vegetarian diets provide an abundance of vitamins and minerals which support overall health.
text2: Certain nutrients are present in lower quantities in vegetarian sources or are absorbed less efficiently by the body compared to those in meat or fish.

text1: Many vegetarians eat fish and/or supplement these nutrients.
text2: Certain nutrients are present in lower quantities in vegetarian sources or are absorbed less efficiently by the body compared to those in meat or fish.

text1: Plant-based food is rich in antioxidants, which helps protect the body's cells from oxidative stress and inflammation.
text2: Some of the foods that reverse oxidative stress are also typically present in carnivore diets such as carotenoids and lycopene.

text1: Creatine is not an essential nutrient as it is naturally produced in the human body.
text2: It also contains creatine, which helps fuel muscles.

text1: Creatine is easily supplemented and even meat-eaters often do so due to its benefits mainly in regards to strength training.
text2: It also contains creatine, which helps fuel muscles.

text1: The human body naturally produces creatine on its own, and it is not necessary to get it through diet.
text2: Meat and fish are the natural sources of creatine, which is fundamental for the muscle building process.

text1: Vegetarians can still eat fish.
text2: Meat and fish are the natural sources of creatine, which is fundamental for the muscle building process.

text1: It is possible to be a vegetarian bodybuilder; which shows that meat is not the only way to increase and maintain muscle mass.
text2: Meat helps increasing and maintaining muscle mass.

text1: Vegetarian diets for pregnant women are perfectly feasible, assuming a varied diet of "healthy fruits, vegetables, legumes and nuts".
text2: According to some studies, newborns of vegetarian mothers are more likely to have low birth weight.

text1: All pregnant and breastfeeding women have to supplement their diets in some way.
text2: Pregnant and breastfeeding women, if vegetarian, need to supplement heavily to get adequate nutrients.

text1: Testing on animals is unethical.
text2: According to utilitarian theory, animal testing is ethically permissible as it maximizes well-being for humans.

text1: Testing cosmetic and household products on animals does not lead to a potential cure for any sort of human illness. It merely sacrifices animal lives for the sake of human convenience.
text2: Ingredients used in cosmetic and household products can be useful in the pharmaceutical industry.

text1: Humans have an ethical obligation to minimise animal suffering.
text2: The obligation to minimise animal suffering is superseded in this case by the obligation to minimise the human suffering, which may be achieved through scientific and medicinal advancement as a direct result of animal research.

text1: It's unethical to subject millions of thinking, feeling animals to life in a laboratory cage.
text2: This line of reasoning would ban prisons, tough jobs, and other harsh human situations. Given that freedom from pain, loneliness, and fear are not human rights, it is not reasonable to demand these rights for an animal.

text1: Animal studies are often poor predictors of human reactions to exposure (p. 1). Therefore it is better to use human test subjects.
text2: Genes can be transferred into rodents to create 'humanized mice', which are used to study diseases and drugs in a way which closely replicates results that might be obtained from human testing.

text1: Some non-human animals have been shown to have higher-order thinking skills.
text2: Animals do not have the capacity to meet the criteria needed to provide informed consent. Therefore they can not be held to this standard.

text1: If consent is a human construct, it can be 'constructed' for animals in a similar manner as it is constructed for those who cannot consent for themselves, such as children or the mentally disabled.
text2: Consent is a human construct, which does not apply to animals.

text1: If consent is a human construct, it can be 'constructed' for animals in a similar manner as it is constructed for those who cannot consent for themselves, such as children or the mentally disabled.
text2: This kind of constructed consent relies on human relatives or guardians who can speak on behalf of those who can't consent. Lab mice and other animals have no such guardians.

text1: Due to the additional costs of the number of staff needed for husbandry, animal testing is actually much more expensive than many non-animal testing methods (p. 16).
text2: Testing on animals is cheaper than testing on humans.

text1: Animal testing is more expensive than alternatives; therefore investing in alternatives is something that corporations are interested in.
text2: Testing on animals is cheaper than testing on humans.

text1: Differences between animals and humans mean that results from animal-based research and testing can be invalid for predicting a human response (p. 45).
text2: Animal testing is often used to test the safety of pharmaceuticals and cosmetics to minimize harm to humans.

text1: Differences between animals and humans mean that results from animal-based research and testing can be invalid for predicting a human response (p. 45).
text2: Genes can be transferred into rodents to create 'humanized mice', which are used to study diseases and drugs in a way which closely replicates results that might be obtained from human testing.

text1: Differences between animals and humans mean that results from animal-based research and testing can be invalid for predicting a human response (p. 45).
text2: While animal models are an imperfect part of the testing process, they remain an invaluable one.

text1: Differences between animals and humans mean that results from animal-based research and testing can be invalid for predicting a human response (p. 45).
text2: Many animals used in research and testing share over 98% of their DNA with humans, meaning that biologically they are very similar.

text1: Due to variation in physiology and genetics, diseases in animals are often substantially different than diseases in humans, meaning that breakthroughs in solving animal diseases don't necessarily translate to helping people (pp. 415-416).
text2: An animal doesn’t need to be identical to a human to be an effective model. It is enough for it to share biological aspects and responses of the disease or system being studied (p. 138).

text1: Animal studies are often poor predictors of human reactions to exposure (p. 1). Therefore it is better to use human test subjects.
text2: The vast majority of biomedical scientists believe that animal studies are essential.

text1: Many of the most common diseases are caused by unhealthy lifestyles, which makes them at least partially avoidable. Many lives could be saved by changing these habits, instead of relying on animals for treatment.
text2: Lifesaving drugs and medicines have come from tests on animals to ensure that products are safe.

text1: Many of the most common diseases are caused by unhealthy lifestyles, which makes them at least partially avoidable. Many lives could be saved by changing these habits, instead of relying on animals for treatment.
text2: There isn't a choice between educating individuals on healthy lifestyles and doing scientific research on diseases that aren't affected by lifestyles. We can do both for maximum effect.

text1: Animal studies are often poor predictors of human reactions to exposure (p. 1). Therefore it is better to use human test subjects.
text2: The vast majority of biomedical scientists believe that animal studies are essential.

text1: While some diseases have been eradicated with help from animal research in the past, there is no reason to continue animal testing when more modern, animal-free alternatives have become available since.
text2: A number of life-threatening childhood diseases, such as polio, have been eradicated entirely in many areas due to a process which involved animal testing.

text1: The cost of rat husbandry is kept down due to the use of inhumane practices, such as using carbon dioxide to cull animals rather than the less painful lethal injection or decapitation methods.
text2: In the US, even the most specialised lab rats generally cost under $500 to procure (p. 9).

text1: Animal testing is more expensive than alternatives; therefore investing in alternatives is something that corporations are interested in.
text2: When choosing to invest in scientific advancements, there are more factors for corporations to consider than merely the immediate financial implications (pp. 21-28).

text1: There are many scientific methods which can be used instead of experimentation on animal subjects.
text2: Not all alternative methods can accurately replicate results in a live host. For example, inconsistencies from cell culture tests can be misleading and may result in effective treatments being prematurely dismissed (p. 55).

text1: There are many scientific methods which can be used instead of experimentation on animal subjects.
text2: Animal testing can provide valuable information on likely side effects and reactions to medical treatments (p. 9).

text1: The Body Shop, a leading cosmetics and beauty product retailer, has supported a ban on animal testing for such goods, demonstrating they are not necessary.
text2: In 2006, The Body Shop came under criticism after its founder sold the company to L'Oreal, who are known to allow animal testing on their cosmetics ingredients.

text1: Not vaccinating children is a form of child-endangerment.
text2: Vaccines can harm children more than the disease they are claimed to prevent.

text1: Most parents are not medical specialists and have no special sixth sense to know what is good for their child and what not (medically speaking).
text2: Parents are in the unique position of knowing their child closely on an individual level. This means that they are in the best position to know what is in the best interest of their child.

text1: Parents are often emotive in their decision making rather than rational. They are more likely to be swayed by questionable but emotive anti-vaccine sources than medical professionals who are better able to discern scientific evidence from pseudoscience.
text2: Parents are in the unique position of knowing their child closely on an individual level. This means that they are in the best position to know what is in the best interest of their child.

text1: It's unclear what special knowledge a parent has about their child at two months (when most doctors recommend children be vaccinated against polio) in terms of deciding whether or not to vaccinate their child that a medical professional also would not have.
text2: Parents are in the unique position of knowing their child closely on an individual level. This means that they are in the best position to know what is in the best interest of their child.

text1: The decision of a parent might be detrimental to a child. The government can step in before this detriment occurs.
text2: Governments can only act _in loco parentis_ or “in place of the parents.” The decision making role lies with the child’s parent or guardian.

text1: Because children have neither the capability nor experience to adequately speak for themselves, the government assumes the mantle to advocate for their interests.
text2: Governments can only act _in loco parentis_ or “in place of the parents.” The decision making role lies with the child’s parent or guardian.

text1: In many jurisdictions, courts can overrule parents' decisions, and in some cases there are certain procedures that courts must approve in advance.
text2: Permission of the parents is first required in order to carry out medical procedures on those under the age of 18.

text1: The link between these symptoms and the HPV vaccine was debunked by a Kyoto University researcher.
text2: Citing reports of serious chronic pain and neurological symptoms, Japan suspended its recommendation of the HPV vaccine for teenagers in 2013.

text1: In December 2015, the World Health Organization issued a statement criticizing the government’s decision to cease recommending the vaccine, saying that “policy decisions based on weak evidence, leading to lack of use of safe and effective vaccines, can result in real harm.”source
text2: Citing reports of serious chronic pain and neurological symptoms, Japan suspended its recommendation of the HPV vaccine for teenagers in 2013.

text1: No drug has zero risks, all drugs have side effects. Benefit risks ratio are used to evaluate the risks of any drugs. In the cases of vaccines benefits far outweigh the potential risks.
text2: Despite being rare, vaccines do have recorded side effects

text1: This is only in very rare cases and when routine immunisation is poor. Since 2000 only 24 outbreaksof vaccine-derived polio were detected in 21 countries.
text2: On rare occasions the polio vaccine can continue to circulate for a long time. If this is allowed to occur, the vaccine-virus sometimes mutates into a form that can cause paralysis.

text1: It does not matter that vaccines do not prevent infection 100% of the time because reduced possibility of infection by a large margin for a majority of the population is much better than no reduction.
text2: Prevention is not 100%. Having the vaccine does not ensure a person will not get sick any more than wearing a condom guarantees a person won't get pregnant or catch/pass on an STD.

text1: The same public health advocates who recommend vaccination also recommend hand washing and staying home if you're sick.  You get all three messages if you get your flu shot at the pharmacy or a public health location (school, health department).
text2: Vaccines may create a false sense of security, leading people to behave in ways that are more reckless.

text1: Not in the US.  CDC studied 8.5 million people given vaccines containing the A(H1N1)pdm09 virus strain used in the US and found no risk.
text2: 1 in 55,000 of the 6 million swine flu vaccines administered in the UK were found to have triggered narcolepsy.

text1: Every new vaccine should be evaluated based on the risk/ benefit ratio, including the urgency of epidemics.
text2: Historically, some vaccines have been pulled from the market due to serious side effects.

text1: Every new vaccine should be evaluated based on the risk/ benefit ratio, including the urgency of epidemics.
text2: Individuals who died as a result of taking vaccines would have been better off taking their chances with the illness.

text1: This is only in very rare cases. The chances of contracting the disease the vaccine is preventing against is often much higher.
text2: In rare cases, vaccines can trigger a serious allergic reaction known as anaphylactic shock. This can develop quickly and is potentially life-threatening.

text1: This study found a 0.65 in a million per-dosage rate of anaphylaxis from vaccines. This is less than my chances of getting hit by lightning this year (1 in 700,000)
text2: In rare cases, vaccines can trigger a serious allergic reaction known as anaphylactic shock. This can develop quickly and is potentially life-threatening.

text1: Death is a side effect of many authorized drugs and procedures.
text2: Death, which is a known side effect of vaccines, cannot be considered an acceptable risk, however rare.

text1: The death of one person is better than the death of 160,000.
text2: Death, which is a known side effect of vaccines, cannot be considered an acceptable risk, however rare.

text1: All medication and medical procedures have side effects. This is no reason to ignore the benefits derived from them.
text2: Despite being rare, vaccines do have recorded side effects

text1: Even though illegal, most doping regimens are done under the supervision of a doctor.
text2: Even when used under medical supervision, the use of PEDs carries serious health risks.

text1: Having doctors tasked with monitoring doping, and able to operate in a legal capacity, would allow them to collaborate openly with other doctors to find safe approaches to steroid use.
text2: As with other team support staff, doctors would likely work under non-disclosure agreements and non-compete clauses, making collaboration across teams challenging.

text1: Athletes have traditionally pursued every possible advantage in the 'spirit of competition' - steroid use is no different.
text2: Steroid use goes against the spirit of competition.

text1: Competition has never been fair as it is heavily based on genetics, diet, upbringing and so forth. As such there is no such thing as fair competition in sports.
text2: Steroid use goes against the spirit of competition.

text1: Legalising the use of steroids will discourage cheating behaviours in sports.
text2: There will always be an incentive to gain a competitive advantage. This will mean that clubs and athletes will be incentivised to seek out newer, riskier drugs that their competitors don't yet have access to.

text1: There would be very little incentive for athletes to lie, since steroid use would be legal.
text2: Even if steroids are legal, many of the same incentives (e.g. to get ahead of other competitors, to keep their advantage secret) could drive athletes to not disclose, or lie about, which steroids they are using, despite them being legal.

text1: If steroids were legal and widely used it is unlikely there would be any stigma against their use.
text2: Another motivation for athletes to lie about steroid use would be to maintain a 'clean' public image.

text1: If steroids were legal and widely used it is unlikely there would be any stigma against their use.
text2: Although it is possible attitudes would change over time, steroid use is currently associated with lying, cheating and athletes who have been stripped of awards. That stigma would survive even if steroids became legal (and permissible within the rules of sporting tournaments).

text1: Legalising the use of PEDs will create transparency and allow regulation of the market.
text2: Regulation companies wouldn't be able to catch up with the newer, more advanced drugs being created.

text1: Steroid use is completely voluntary. Individuals should be able to consent to steroid use since no third parties are harmed.
text2: Legalising steroids would force all athletes to take steroids if they wanted to remain competitive.

text1: Steroid use is completely voluntary. Individuals should be able to consent to steroid use since no third parties are harmed.
text2: The requirements of staying competitive as a professional athlete are too coercive. Individuals cannot consent to steroid use under such circumstances.

text1: Steroids allow people who lack genetic advantages to compete with those who have them.
text2: If everyone took steroids, everyone would gain an equal benefit and those with genetic advantages would still outperform those without.

text1: Competition has never been fair as it is heavily based on genetics, diet, upbringing and so forth. As such there is no such thing as fair competition in sports.
text2: Drugs bring unfairness to the next level as the athletes in some countries have more technology and developed drugs whereas some don't.

text1: Sports change their rules all the time. It isn't a bad thing for the focus of a sport to change.
text2: Legalising steroids will change the nature and focus of sports.

text1: Athletes disinterested in steroid use would still have the option of joining traditional leagues.
text2: Legalising steroids will change the nature and focus of sports.

text1: The introduction of new technology in sports hasn't fundamentally changed the focus or nature of sports.
text2: Legalising steroids will change the nature and focus of sports.

text1: Since steroid use is commonplace, it makes sense to alter the rules to allow all players to engage in it.
text2: Legalising steroids would force all athletes to take steroids if they wanted to remain competitive.

text1: Legalising steroids will allow for the regulation of steroids to ensure their safety.
text2: Many common steroids used for doping are approved by the FDA and other agencies for medical purposes.

text1: If steroid use is legal, players will be able to seek medical advice and supervision when using steroids.
text2: Even though illegal, most doping regimens are done under the supervision of a doctor.

text1: Currently athletes who are exceptional are often suspected of steroid use, even if they are passing drug tests. Their achievements are being undermined and discredited by rumour and suspicion surrounding steroid use.
text2: The current culture condemning PEDs means that legalization will not undermine people's tendency to discredit the accomplishments of suspected dopers.

text1: Steroid use is completely voluntary. Individuals should be able to consent to steroid use since no third parties are harmed.
text2: In contact sports, a player who is unnaturally strong and fast poses a physical danger to the other players.

text1: Individuals can choose not to be athletes if they do not wish to use steroids.
text2: We should not force athletes to have to chose between their health/safety and their career/passion.

text1: Competition could be divided into 'enhanced' and 'normal' categories. Any legal enhancement would be allowed in 'Enhanced' competition.
text2: Steroid use takes the onus off the athlete and puts it in the hands of governments or company's that can spend to create cutting-edge PED. This means an average athlete in skill belonging to a large company will be equivalent to a talented athlete belonging to a small company. This would widen the gap between the effects of science and the natural born talent of an athlete.

text1: Competition could be divided into 'enhanced' and 'normal' categories. Any legal enhancement would be allowed in 'Enhanced' competition.
text2: With drug usage allowed, athletes may consume substances to the detriment of their health, mental or physical.

text1: Even within the same medical constraints, peaks in flu infections do not result in higher mortality in the same way as peaks in Covid-19 infections did.
text2: Higher mortality of Covid-19 could be due to medical constraints created by the sudden influx of patients over a short period of time.

text1: As of March 26, 2021, the US has conducted nearly 400 million tests, more than any other country.
text2: In the US, Covid-19 testing was not as rigorous or as consistent across states as was in other countries.

text1: Based on early reporting figures and adjustments for reporting delays, various countries with significant outbreaks saw significant excess mortality.
text2: The actual Covid-19 death rate must be estimated based on a calculated excess mortality rate, as not all Covid-19 infected persons are being tested, but only a selected subset of them.

text1: While there are reasonable concerns about long-term increases in mortality due to economic deprivation and reduction in physical fitness or mental health, those are things that would impact long-term mortality, and not contribute to excess mortality in any given week.
text2: An interpretation of the observed excess mortality numbers should also be cautiously done, as the quarantine measures do have an impact on the mortality rate.

text1: People weren't driving or walking near busy roads, thereby preventing traffic accidents.
text2: One study found that even though Americans are driving less, traffic fatalities actually increased as more people drove recklessly on emptier roads.

text1: In January 2021, Covid-19 reinfections caused milder infections and therefore were unlikely to add significantly to the death rate.
text2: Insufficient tracking made it challenging to estimate the extent of Covid-19 reinfections.

text1: Since the virus emerged, numerous estimations of Covid-19 death rates were made, becoming increasingly accurate over time.
text2: Death rate for Covid-19 could not be accurately estimated due to inadequacies in data.

text1: Covid-19 infections overwhelmed health systems due to the sharp increase in people requiring hospitalization and respiratory support.
text2: Covid-19 cases would be less likely to overwhelm health systems if the systems weren't already dysfunctional in many countries.

text1: The rate of spread is relevant to a virus' ability to overrun healthcare systems if the hospitalization rate is high, even if the death rate is low.
text2: Only when the propagation rates of viruses are coupled with their corresponding death rates per infected person is it possible to compare their dangerousness.

text1: Many European countries that have highly ranked healthcare systems experienced great difficulties during the pandemic.
text2: Countries that had strong public heath responses were able to contain Covid-19 infections relatively successfully.

text1: The number of asymptomatic cases cannot be seriously estimated at the beginning of a pandemic as a statistical study would be necessary by having a representative sample of the population tested once the pandemic is over. That way, it is easier to assess who had it without knowing it, who had it and did have the symptoms, and who had it and most probably died from it.
text2: When sample populations were tested and monitored over an extended period, as many as 28% of cases were asymptomatic for the entire period of illness.

text1: This is a good reason to discount the US mortality data, but not a good reason to discount mortality data from countries with significantly better testing regimens, like South Korea.
text2: In the US, Covid-19 testing was not as rigorous or as consistent across states as was in other countries.

text1: Based on early reporting figures and adjustments for reporting delays, various countries with significant outbreaks saw significant excess mortality.
text2: An interpretation of the observed excess mortality numbers should also be cautiously done, as the quarantine measures do have an impact on the mortality rate.

text1: Increased hospitalization of Covid-19 patients due to a malfunctioning health system still entailed that it is dangerous, even if only contingently so.
text2: Covid-19 cases would be less likely to overwhelm health systems if the systems weren't already dysfunctional in many countries.

text1: Inadequate testing suggests that the actual fatality rate was higher than reported, not lower. This further entailed that it was deadlier than the flu.
text2: Not all people who were infected with the Covid-19 virus were identified. This made it challenging to calculate the actual fatality rate.

text1: Even without accurate rates, the possible range of the fatality rate strongly indicated that Covid-19 was deadlier than the seasonal flu.
text2: Death rate for Covid-19 could not be accurately estimated due to inadequacies in data.

text1: Mutations often lead to an increase in the number of deaths. By that trend, mutations made Covid-19 even more dangerous than it already was.
text2: As flu viruses undergo mutations, it is difficult to make predictions about the rate of death. In Italy, the total number of flu-related deaths during the 2014-2015 season was 65.6% higher compared to the previous season.

text1: Even if vaccination reduced the mortality rate, part of the world population has not received a Covid-19 vaccination.
text2: Death rates reduced dramatically after the Covid-19 vaccine was rolled out and administered.

text1: Covid-19 infections overwhelmed health systems due to the sharp increase in people requiring hospitalization and respiratory support.
text2: Hospitals have previously been overwhelmed by influenza patients as well.

text1: Covid-19 infections overwhelmed health systems due to the sharp increase in people requiring hospitalization and respiratory support.
text2: Hospitalization among Covid-19 patients fell significantly after vaccination.

text1: Disease experts estimate that each Covid-19 sufferer infected between 2 to 3 others.
text2: The rate of spread alone does not prove how dangerous a virus is.

text1: 61,000 people died as a result of this epidemic. In comparison, 350,000 people lost their lives to the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.
text2: There was a flu epidemic in the US in 2017-2018, which overwhelmed hospitals in nearly every state.

text1: Hospitalization required by severe forms of Covid-19 and seasonal influenza infections differed considerably.
text2: Hospitals have previously been overwhelmed by influenza patients as well.

text1: New variants of Covid-19 could be relatively more resistant to vaccines.
text2: Hospitalization among Covid-19 patients fell significantly after vaccination.

text1: Preventing people from contracting Covid-19 became extremely difficult without a vaccine.
text2: Even with vaccines, 100% protection from either the flu or Covid-19 is not guaranteed.

text1: Covid-19 poses a greater risk than the flu for those without access to vaccines.
text2: The risk was low for the vast majority of people who tested positive for Covid-19, with only 2% needing intensive care.

text1: HPV can betransmitted to newborns during pregnancy and birth. This is not prevented by condom usage.
text2: HPV is a sexually transmitted disease. As long as sexually active people use contraception (condoms) correctly, there is no need for compulsory vaccination.

text1: A 2011 meta-analysis evaluated the results of seven separate randomized control tests, and found that HPV vaccines are safe, well tolerated, and highly efficacious in preventing persistent infections and cervical diseases.
text2: This study also concluded that "Questions related to long-term efficacy and safety" of the HPV vaccine "have yet to be addressed."

text1: A 2014 meta-analysis evaluated the results of 15 previous scientific studies (10 randomized control tests and five observational studies). It found the effectiveness of the vaccines in preventing HPV 16 and 18 (the two most serious strains) ranged from 83% to 94%.
text2: Of the studies included in this meta-analysis, "Only one study was not initiated and funded by a vaccine manufacturer." The purpose of this review was also to assess the long-term effectiveness of the vaccine, and only two studies were considered long-term (6-7 years), one of which had a "high" risk of bias, and overall evidence quality was "low to very low".

text1: Only four out of the 195,270 vaccinated individuals (0.002%) reported a serious side effect (one warranting a trip to the hospital).
text2: A research study published in April 2016 tracked the rate of adverse events following immunization among women and girls aged nine and older in Canada between 2006 and 2014. The study found that out of 195,270 girls and women vaccinated, 192 reported adverse events.

text1: HPV vaccine contains about 0.5 mg of aluminum per dose. Most teens and adults "ingest" 5-10 mg of aluminum per day from food, water and other (industrial/occupational) exposures.
text2: The HPV vaccine contains aluminum, a known neurotoxin that can be persistent in the body and be carried by macrophages to the brain, where it accumulates.

text1: Anaphylaxis only occurs if the patient is allergic to the vaccination, in which case they should not take it at all. It is not something inherent in the vaccine, and a significant majority will not experience it.
text2: The vaccine has potential side effects, which range from more mild (pain at the injection site, fever and fainting) to adverse effects (anaphylaxis). It therefore should not be made compulsory.

text1: The side effects are generally mild, and short-term. There is no evidence to support the idea that the long-term serious adverse events listed are caused by the vaccines.
text2: The vaccine has potential side effects, which range from more mild (pain at the injection site, fever and fainting) to adverse effects (anaphylaxis). It therefore should not be made compulsory.

text1: Several trials and studies have proven HPV vaccines to be safe, with extremely low rates of serious possible side effects. What little scientific research has been done contradicting this consensus has consistently been shown to be flawed and unreliable.
text2: The vaccine has potential side effects, which range from more mild (pain at the injection site, fever and fainting) to adverse effects (anaphylaxis). It therefore should not be made compulsory.

text1: The potential side effects of the vaccine are negligible compared to the potential risk of contracting HPV.
text2: The vaccine has potential side effects, which range from more mild (pain at the injection site, fever and fainting) to adverse effects (anaphylaxis). It therefore should not be made compulsory.

text1: Cervical cancer is the fourth-most common cancer among women worldwide, and has a 52% global mortality rate. Two of the four cancer-causing strains of HPV targeted by the vaccine are responsible for ~70% of cervical cancer cases.
text2: One out of 100 women gets infected with the specific types of HPV that the vaccines are developed for. Hence mandatory vaccination appears to be an excessive measure.

text1: One out of a 100 is a very high number, that is one percent of the female population of a country. Vaccinating them, in order to save them and eliminate the cost of treating them for that cancer, is a very small price to pay.
text2: One out of 100 women gets infected with the specific types of HPV that the vaccines are developed for. Hence mandatory vaccination appears to be an excessive measure.

text1: The linked page in the above statement says that 15% of women in the United States are infected with the high risk types which cause cancer and that the vaccine helps protect against two of them which are the cause of 90% of cervical cancers.
text2: One out of 100 women gets infected with the specific types of HPV that the vaccines are developed for. Hence mandatory vaccination appears to be an excessive measure.

text1: It is valid to use a surrogate endpoint (reduction in HPV infection) when that surrogate is known to be a precursor of the ultimate clinical endpoint (in this case, cancer) and when decades of follow-up would be required to observe any reduction in the clinical endpoint. Cervical cancer develops decades after initial infection with HPV.
text2: To gain licensure, the HPV vaccine manufacturers were not required to and did not provide studies showing that the vaccine actually reduces the risk of cancer. Instead, the FDA used the surrogate marker of antibody titers against the target strains of HPV considered to be protective. As noted in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute in 2014, "it may be many years before the effect on HPV vaccination on the incidence of cervical cancer can be assessed."

text1: Countries would benefit financially from mandatory HPV vaccinations.
text2: Vaccines can have potential long-term side effects that also create burdens on the public. It is impossible to accurately calculate the cost/benefit of each choice from a financial viewpoint in a future where technology may change.

text1: The HPV virus is sufficiently harmful to mandate compulsory vaccination.
text2: The viral infection, more often than not, clears to undetectable levels by itself.

text1: The HPV virus is sufficiently harmful to mandate compulsory vaccination.
text2: Heart attacks are "sufficiently harmful" but we do not mandate healthy diet and exercise by regulation in order to prevent them.

text1: Getting a HPV vaccination is better than treating genital warts after they have occurred.
text2: This claim is strictly an opinion. People seriously injured by the HPV vaccine would likely feel differently about it.

text1: There is no treatment for the virus itself although health problems caused by HPV can be treated. It is better to be vaccinated and avoid the infection than invest time and money in treating problems caused by it.
text2: The argument "It is better..." is strictly an opinion that others may disagree with. For example, one might consider the potential risk from the vaccine of its use of aluminum adjuvant, a known neurotoxin that scientists now know is persistent in the body and accumulates in the brain, and decide that routine pap smears are sufficient.

text1: Once the HPV virus enters the bloodstream, it cannot be eliminated. As the symptoms often don't appear in time for adequate treatment, a vaccination is the most effective way of dealing with the virus.
text2: There are no studies showing that HPV vaccines are more effective at reducing the risk of cancer compared to routine pap smear screening.

text1: Genital warts treatment can cost anywhere between $300 to $8000, whereas a complete series of HPV vaccinations costs $450.
text2: This argument is implying that HPV vaccination provides a net economic benefit to society, but the two costs presented are not the only costs that need to be considered to make that judgment. Other costs requiring consideration include the costs to society from vaccine injury and the opportunity cost of directing funding toward vaccination.

text1: Anaphylaxis only occurs if the patient is allergic to the vaccination, in which case they should not take it at all. It is not something inherent in the vaccine, and a significant majority will not experience it.
text2: Patients are warned about three major possible allergens contained in the HPV vaccine; yeast, amorphous aluminium hydroxyphosphate sulfate, and polysorbate 80. While most people would be aware of an allergy they have to yeast, the other two allergens are not regularly encountered by most people, so it is likely some people will not know if they are allergic to them until after they receive the vaccine and have an adverse reaction.

text1: Several trials and studies have proven HPV vaccines to be safe, with extremely low rates of serious possible side effects. What little scientific research has been done contradicting this consensus has consistently been shown to be flawed and unreliable.
text2: When there is a potential harm, no matter how small, from a medical procedure, it is unethical to force that medical procedure because it violates informed consent regardless of the severity of those potential side effects.

text1: It is valid to use a surrogate endpoint (reduction in HPV infection) when that surrogate is known to be a precursor of the ultimate clinical endpoint (in this case, cancer) and when decades of follow-up would be required to observe any reduction in the clinical endpoint. Cervical cancer develops decades after initial infection with HPV.
text2: Because the cancer takes 10 to 20 years to develop, it is difficult to assess the effect of HPV vaccinations on cancer outcomes.

text1: The HPV virus is sufficiently harmful to mandate compulsory vaccination.
text2: The current HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) only vaccinates for 9 HPV strains, however according to the CDC, there are at least 13 HPV strains that can cause cancer, so a mandatory vaccination does not address the totality of the issue, and could lead to a false sense of security.

text1: Countries would benefit financially from mandatory HPV vaccinations.
text2: Citizens should not be subjected to forced healthcare, regardless of benefit, because it is cost effective.

text1: Routine Pap testing cannot treat or prevent outbreaks of genital warts.
text2: There are no studies showing that HPV vaccines are more effective at reducing the risk of cancer compared to routine pap smear screening.

text1: The proliferation of smoking advertising and product placement creates false information - true choice can only be made when informed.
text2: The smoker is aware of the risks.

text1: The proliferation of smoking advertising and product placement creates false information - true choice can only be made when informed.
text2: Many countries have laws that ensure informed decision, such as warning labels on cigarette packs. It does not call for a complete ban.

text1: Smoking does not actually relieve stress. In fact, it may even cause more tension and anxiety.
text2: Nicotine can also have helpful effects on the body, such as reducing depression and irritability, improving one's mood, and enhancing both short-term memory and concentration.

text1: Smoking does not actually relieve stress. In fact, it may even cause more tension and anxiety.
text2: This is only the case if people smoke excessively. As long as people smoke in moderate amounts, it won't cause more tension or anxiety and can be seen as a coping mechanism for people who feel like the alternatives aren't working for them.

text1: Life expectancy in developed countries is over 70 years. If smokers die on average 10 years before compared to non-smokers, that means they die being around 60 years old. At that age, most people have already had children, therefore there is no reduction of population growth.
text2: Death from smoking is their own fault and helps limit population growth

text1: This is a slippery slope fallacy. Cigarettes becoming banned does not imply any product deemed harmful at any level would be banned. Each product would be considered on a case by case basis.
text2: Banning cigarettes sets a dangerous precedent for banning any product deemed harmful to health. Most processed foods have unhealthy amounts of salts, sugars and fat.

text1: Autonomy is not always valued in society over health.
text2: Everyone should have the right to make their own decisions in regards to their health.

text1: If this was the case, then euthanasia would be allowed in cases of terminal illness. However since it remains illegal in most places, clearly autonomy in regards to personal health is not deemed necessary by society.
text2: In several European countries euthanasia is in fact legal and there are movements pushing for legalization in places such as the United States. Perhaps autonomy will be deemed necessary or at least valued more in the near future.

text1: If this was the case, then euthanasia would be allowed in cases of terminal illness. However since it remains illegal in most places, clearly autonomy in regards to personal health is not deemed necessary by society.
text2: Euthanasia may be illegal in some places as it requires positive actions by other people (usually doctors) and a complex medical and social culture. Euthanasia is not a strictly autonomous action, and the fact that it is illegal in most places does not speak to the value of autonomy in society.

text1: Although certain forms of Euthanasia require positive action by other people, there are forms that minimize that action by putting the burden of the act on the sick person themselves. This includes the work by Dr. Kevorkian, who only provided the means for sick people to end their own lives. As these forms also remain illegal, it is clear that the larger discussion of euthanasia is not concerned with personal autonomy.
text2: Euthanasia may be illegal in some places as it requires positive actions by other people (usually doctors) and a complex medical and social culture. Euthanasia is not a strictly autonomous action, and the fact that it is illegal in most places does not speak to the value of autonomy in society.

text1: Increasing the death rate is not the only way to deal with the effects of overpopulation. Many other measures can have a positive impact on overpopulation.
text2: There are already too many people living on this planet. This provision may help with issues related to overpopulation.

text1: The impact of this provision on the death rate would be insignificant and thus it should not be considered a relevant benefit.
text2: There are already too many people living on this planet. This provision may help with issues related to overpopulation.

text1: Evidence suggests that there are no significant numbers of voluntary deaths with a legal right to die.
text2: The number of voluntary deaths tripled in the Netherlands reaching 4800 in 2013.

text1: If fewer people are availing of niche life-saving treatments by choosing to end their lives there will not be economies of scale which could reduce treatment costs and increase access for everyone in the future.
text2: The right to die could reduce medical costs by allowing people to die instead of continuing to receive expensive treatment.

text1: Not only adults are smokers. Many young people replicate behaviours of adults without realizing the risk.
text2: Adults are traditionally allowed to do many things that contain risk or self harm. The most common approach is to ensure they are aware of the risks so they can make informed choices

text1: Smoking is detrimental to the health of the smoker.
text2: The smoker is aware of the risks.

text1: Smoking is detrimental to the health of the smoker.
text2: By that standard, sugar, tee or even coffee should be banned. That is a restriction on life itself. It disrespects the human as an individual capable of making their own decisions.

text1: Smoking is detrimental to the health of the smoker.
text2: Death from smoking is their own fault and helps limit population growth

text1: Smoking is detrimental to the health of the smoker.
text2: Everyone should have the right to make their own decisions in regards to their health.

text1: Secondhand smoke is damaging to the health of non-smokers.
text2: Everyone should have the right to make their own decisions in regards to their health.

text1: Secondhand smoke is damaging to the health of non-smokers.
text2: No one is being forced to be around people while they smoke

text1: Smokers take up beds in hospitals as well as the time of researchers who could be focused on something else.
text2: Everyone should have the right to make their own decisions in regards to their health.

text1: Fear of being publicly shamed for failing to comply would likely outweigh the temporary inconvenience of wearing a mask.
text2: Public shaming does not work as it makes people defensive and thus more stubbornly defiant.

text1: Fear of being publicly shamed for failing to comply would likely outweigh the temporary inconvenience of wearing a mask.
text2: Some people, namely men, find wearing a mask to be "shameful" or a sign of "weakness" and they, therefore, avoid it despite the thread of public shaming.

text1: Studies in behavioural psychology in the context of a disaster show that humans are naturally inclined to unite in solidarity with the community.
text2: People are more likely to put the individual inconvenience of wearing a mask above the collective good.

text1: Seeing mask-wearing as a social practice based on values such as shared responsibility and solidarity is likely to increase its prevalence.
text2: People are more likely to put the individual inconvenience of wearing a mask above the collective good.

text1: There are other key identifiers that can help police apprehend a criminal beyond facial features.
text2: Masks hide part of the face, making it harder for the police to retrieve the identity of (possible) criminals.

text1: There have been concerns that wearing masks makes communication difficult for people who are deaf or hard-of-hearing.
text2: Some experts have called for transparent masks, which allow for lip-reading, to address communication challenges for the deaf community.

text1: If all humans die from a pandemic, environmental conditions will matter little to humans.
text2: COVID-19 has a 1.4% fatality rate. All humans will not die from this pandemic.

text1: Whether something will happen in practice or not should not overshadow a debate on whether something should happen.
text2: A debate about a real world policy cannot be divorced from what it will look like on the ground, and how people will respond.

text1: Public health and public safety will generally improve as a result of mask-wearing, both now and in the future.
text2: Masks hide part of the face, making it harder for the police to retrieve the identity of (possible) criminals.

text1: Most of the major health and safety implications arising from environmental problems will not transpire in the short to medium term. Therefore, the distinction between environmental concerns and present heath and safety challenges is justified.
text2: There are many people facing the reality of the climate crisis today. Flooding and forest fires are just two examples of this.

text1: We should put safety and health ahead of environmental concerns.
text2: This draws a false dichotomy between protecting health and safety and dealing with environmental issues. They are heavily intertwined.

text1: The state does not wish to impose masks as an object of fashion or to enforce a stylistic norm. Masks are primarily medical tools that happen to be objects of clothing.
text2: North Korea enforces stringent styling rules on its people.

text1: That liberal and democratic states are also mandating masks suggest that such a policy is not inherently oppressive.
text2: Enforced clothing is a hallmark of oppressive regimes.

text1: Clothing restrictions or prescriptions often target specific groups of a population, which is what makes these directives oppressive. Masks, however, should be worn by everyone, regardless of gender, status, or religious affiliation, for example.
text2: Enforced clothing is a hallmark of oppressive regimes.

text1: If everyone wore masks then the benefits would be equal.
text2: Mandating wearing masks is coercive because it disproprotionately benefits people around more than the ones wearing them.

text1: The right of a person to choose how they dress is not absolute.
text2: One of the most intuitively important human freedoms is the right to bodily autonomy. This includes how people choose to dress.

text1: Many jobs require staff to wear uniforms, sometimes including masks, yet this is not seen as an infringement on human freedom.
text2: An employee whose employer requires them to wear a mask is not analogous to members of the public being forced to wear one because the employee has freely entered into this contractual relationship with the employer.

text1: The right to bodily autonomy cannot infringe upon the rights of others. Not wearing a mask threatens other people's right to life and well-being.
text2: One of the most intuitively important human freedoms is the right to bodily autonomy. This includes how people choose to dress.

text1: While improper use hinders the effectiveness of masks, many people will still use them correctly and gain the benefits they provide.
text2: Improper use and lack of knowledge about masks hinder the effectiveness of wearing masks.

text1: While this is possible, it is extremely rare for someone to contract COVID-19 through their eyes.
text2: People can contract COVID-19 from virus particles entering their eyes, which most masks do not cover.

text1: While the virus can survive on some surfaces, it is unlikely to spread by touch.
text2: Masks will not prevent people from contracting or spreading the disease in other ways.

text1: Most people support making masks mandatory in public places.
text2: The majority of people supporting a policy is not a good reason to implement that policy.

text1: Most people support making masks mandatory in public places.
text2: If most people do support mask-wearing, then they would choose to wear masks even without them being mandated by the government.

text1: Data from several countries shows that public opinion is firmly in favour of mandating mask-wearing.
text2: Even if everyone is in favour of wearing masks in theory, not everyone can afford to buy masks.
